{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3142338,"name":"Yohan Behaghel","username":"YoyoB5553","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/e47c2d/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T11:44:08.506Z","cooked":"

Hey ChiefDelphi,
I’m from team 5553 and this year we’re planning to use 2 speed 3 flacons gearboxs. However, our 84T 20DP Aluminium Spur Gear bought with VexPro are being eaten by the 10T motor pignions from the falcons. Does any of you have an idea of the cause of this problem ?
Thanks

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2023-02-09T11:44:08.506Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":73,"reads":658,"readers_count":657,"score":526.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426222,"topic_slug":"gears-being-eaten","display_username":"Yohan Behaghel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/how-do-you-feel-about-tacos/426204/10","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"How do you feel about tacos?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50028,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CAD"},"post_url":"/t/gears-being-eaten/426222/1","custom_user_title":"CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3142341,"name":"Sean Lavery","username":"Lil_Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T11:55:17.656Z","cooked":"

What do you mean by “being eaten?” Some more detail (or even pictures) can help us provide a more specific solution.

Are the teeth being sheared off the gear? Or are they wearing down to nubs at an accelerated rate? What type of grease or lubrication are you using?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2023-02-09T11:55:17.656Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":648,"readers_count":647,"score":134.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426222,"topic_slug":"gears-being-eaten","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/gears-being-eaten/426222/2","custom_user_title":"FRC 1712","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3142344,"name":"Noam |Galaxia 5987 - 2022 Alumni","username":"Noam_5987","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/noam_5987/{size}/170987_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T12:15:17.604Z","cooked":"

Not too sure about this, but we also had this issue few years ago. Our 9t steel pinion was eating 50t aluminum gear. We decided to switch the aluminum gear to steel and that stopped the problem. So a solution will be to put a steel gear there, but you might find other ways to make it work with regular aluminum gear.

looks like the center distance is wrong. Is this a custom gear box ? Did you calculate the center distance with a 10 tooth and an 84 tooth or 12 tooth 84 tooth? vex 10t motor pinion should be used with a 12 tooth center distance

Yeah we used 12T into 84T with a 60,96mm center distance

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2023-02-09T12:40:46.853Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":505,"readers_count":504,"score":106.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426222,"topic_slug":"gears-being-eaten","display_username":"Yohan Behaghel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":10484,"username":"cmwilson13","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmwilson13/{size}/3628_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50028,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CAD"},"post_url":"/t/gears-being-eaten/426222/9","custom_user_title":"CAD","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3142361,"name":"Aron Rubin","username":"AronRubin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aronrubin/{size}/180072_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T12:57:28.204Z","cooked":"

As a general practice 1) debur your gears /pinion with needle files taking care to kiss the edges and not change the profiles 2) support the shafts from both ends to keep the gears coplanar.

I didn’t appreciate this is a multimotor arrangement. Just how balanced are the outputs of your motors? Not my area of expertise but I think BLDC does not get dragged through commutation the way brushed motors do.

what’s BLDC ?

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2023-02-09T14:30:42.933Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":379,"readers_count":378,"score":95.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":426222,"topic_slug":"gears-being-eaten","display_username":"Yohan Behaghel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51509,"username":"AronRubin","name":"Aron Rubin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aronrubin/{size}/180072_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50028,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CAD"},"post_url":"/t/gears-being-eaten/426222/15","custom_user_title":"CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3142458,"name":"Aron Rubin","username":"AronRubin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aronrubin/{size}/180072_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T15:19:50.218Z","cooked":"

BLDC = BrushLess DC (direct current).
The question I would have is what happens when motor output is mismatched? Assume motor_A races ahead of motor_B by a small amount. What are the effects on each motor? I imagine for brushed motors, like the CIM, motor_A would drag motor_B to its next commutator pad. Likewise, motor_A would be slightly delayed in commutating.

image1838×644 126 KB

However, in a brushless dc motor arrangement, the coils are pulsed by the motor controller, not a physical closed loop. Brushless can have sensor closed-loop (feedback) or run open-loop (feed forward). Assuming open loop, motor_B’s coils will stay energized which I believe will produce more resistance to motor_A dragging it through. That extra force is going to be experienced by the mixing gear. Closed-loop brushless through hall sensors may or may not bring this closer to the brushed arrangement.
image750×421 71.3 KB

I would love for someone who knows more about this topic to weigh in.

BTW All of this assumes alignment is not an issue as mentioned in my previous reply.

For the motor mounting, are you using the motor ring to locate or are you relying on the bolts to locate? If either set of holes is a loose fit, you are effectively increasing the c-c distance. We like to locate using the motor ring and a 19.08-19.12mm hole diameter. Any extra c-c distance with steel-aluminum gears WILL eat the aluminum gear very quickly. Now, back to training the monkeys…

We had this issue in the past, almost made our gear into a perfect circle in 2019. I believe the issue was, as many people have already pointed out, the center to center distance between gears. We used the wrong mounting holes in the transmission plate. Since it looks like you have custom transmission plates, I would triple check all of your measurements.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2023-02-09T16:06:56.201Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":308,"readers_count":307,"score":76.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426222,"topic_slug":"gears-being-eaten","display_username":"Thomas Gilmore","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35350,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/gears-being-eaten/426222/19","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3142499,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-09T16:19:45.360Z","cooked":"

You may want to program an acceleration curve into your controls for these motors. Falcons have high torque at low speeds compared to other motors, and with three of them you’re likely to get a fair amount of lashing from the sudden acceleration/deceleration of the motors.

Also, as others have stated, I would strongly recommend steel gears for this application. Aluminum gears are nice, but not really designed for the 2349W of motor power you’re putting through them. For that matter, depending on what you’re using this for, I wouldn’t be shocked if you actually started doing damage to the hex shaft (or the hex hole of the gear), that’s how much force we’re talking about here.
